events.text: Spring – Emperor Justinian I appoints his cousin Germanus as magister militum to deal with the crisis in Africa. He sends a mobile force of comitatenses (mostly cavalry) and an elite guard. Solomon, the previous magister militum, returns to Constantinople.[4]
events.html: Spring – Emperor Justinian I appoints his cousin Germanus as magister militum to deal with the crisis in Africa. He sends a mobile force of comitatenses (mostly cavalry) and an elite guard. Solomon, the previous magister militum, returns to Constantinople.[4]

events.text: Summer – Gothic War (535–554): Belisarius crosses the Strait of Messina and invades Italy. He conquers the city of Rhegium and advances to Naples.
events.html: Summer – Gothic War (535–554): Belisarius crosses the Strait of Messina and invades Italy. He conquers the city of Rhegium and advances to Naples.

events.text: November – Siege of Naples: Belisarius captures Naples after a month's siege, by sending troops into the city through an abandoned Roman aqueduct.[5]
events.html: November – Siege of Naples: Belisarius captures Naples after a month's siege, by sending troops into the city through an abandoned Roman aqueduct.[5]

events.text: December 9 – Belisarius enters Rome through the Porta Asinaria, and the Gothic garrison of 4,000 men flees the capital. He sends an urgent request for reinforcements to Justinian I, meanwhile preparing Rome for a siege, by bringing in great quantities of food and other supplies.[6]
events.html: December 9 – Belisarius enters Rome through the Porta Asinaria, and the Gothic garrison of 4,000 men flees the capital. He sends an urgent request for reinforcements to Justinian I, meanwhile preparing Rome for a siege, by bringing in great quantities of food and other supplies.[6]

events.text: Winter – Belisarius sets up his headquarters on the Pincian Hill, and repairs the neglected city walls of Rome. He stations a 5,000-man garrison, of whom half are his personal bodyguard (bucellarii). To hold parts of the city, he recruits 20,000 young Romans to man the walls.
events.html: Winter – Belisarius sets up his headquarters on the Pincian Hill, and repairs the neglected city walls of Rome. He stations a 5,000-man garrison, of whom half are his personal bodyguard (bucellarii). To hold parts of the city, he recruits 20,000 young Romans to man the walls.

events.text: Early in 536 (possible) – Extreme weather events of 535–536: A volcano erupts in Iceland.[1] Famine is described in the Annals of Ulster.[7]
events.html: Early in 536 (possible) – Extreme weather events of 535–536: A volcano erupts in Iceland.[1] Famine is described in the Annals of Ulster.[7]

events.text: March – King Theodahad cedes Provence and upper Alamannia to the Franks, gaining their support in the war. He sends a large Gothic army into Dalmatia. They defeat the Byzantines, Mundus is killed during the fighting at Salona, and the Byzantine army withdraws.[6]
events.html: March – King Theodahad cedes Provence and upper Alamannia to the Franks, gaining their support in the war. He sends a large Gothic army into Dalmatia. They defeat the Byzantines, Mundus is killed during the fighting at Salona, and the Byzantine army withdraws.[6]
events.date: March – King Theodahad cedes Provence and upper Alamannia to the Franks, gaining their support in the war. He sends a large Gothic army into Dalmatia. They defeat the Byzantines, Mundus is killed during the fighting at Salona, and the Byzantine army withdraws.[6]

events.text: Summer – Constantinianus, magister militum per Illyricum, retakes Dalmatia. The Goths abandon Salona and withdraw to the north. The Byzantines rebuild its walls and reclaim the province.[8]
events.html: Summer – Constantinianus, magister militum per Illyricum, retakes Dalmatia. The Goths abandon Salona and withdraw to the north. The Byzantines rebuild its walls and reclaim the province.[8]

events.text: December – Vitiges deposes his rival Theodahad at Ravenna, and marries Matasuntha (daughter of queen Amalasuntha). He becomes king of the Ostrogoths and assembles an army to fight against Belisarius.[5]
events.html: December – Vitiges deposes his rival Theodahad at Ravenna, and marries Matasuntha (daughter of queen Amalasuntha). He becomes king of the Ostrogoths and assembles an army to fight against Belisarius.[5]

events.text: March - April – Belisarius sails to Carthage with 1,000 men, to suppress a mutiny against Solomon. Meanwhile, the capital is besieged by 9,000 rebels, including many Vandals, under Stotzas.
events.html: March - April – Belisarius sails to Carthage with 1,000 men, to suppress a mutiny against Solomon. Meanwhile, the capital is besieged by 9,000 rebels, including many Vandals, under Stotzas.
events.date: March - April – Belisarius sails to Carthage with 1,000 men, to suppress a mutiny against Solomon. Meanwhile, the capital is besieged by 9,000 rebels, including many Vandals, under Stotzas.

events.text: Battle of the River Bagradas: Belisarius defeats the mutineers, and hurries back to Sicily.[9]
events.html: Battle of the River Bagradas: Belisarius defeats the mutineers, and hurries back to Sicily.[9]

events.text: January 26 – Senka succeeds his brother Ankan, as the 28th emperor of Japan.
events.html: January 26 – Senka succeeds his brother Ankan, as the 28th emperor of Japan.
events.date: January 26 – Senka succeeds his brother Ankan, as the 28th emperor of Japan.

events.text: August – Volcanic winter of 536: Snow falls in China, which causes the harvest to be delayed.[10]
events.html: August – Volcanic winter of 536: Snow falls in China, which causes the harvest to be delayed.[10]

events.text: Before March 13 – Anthimus I is deposed as patriarch of Constantinople in favour of Menas.
events.html: Before March 13 – Anthimus I is deposed as patriarch of Constantinople in favour of Menas.
events.date: Before March 13 – Anthimus I is deposed as patriarch of Constantinople in favour of Menas.

events.text: April 22 – Pope Agapetus I dies in Constantinople, after a reign of just ten months. He is succeeded by Silverius as the 58th pope.
events.html: April 22 – Pope Agapetus I dies in Constantinople, after a reign of just ten months. He is succeeded by Silverius as the 58th pope.

events.text: The Little Hagia Sophia in Constantinople (begun in 527) is completed as the Church of Saints Sergius and Bacchus.
events.html: The Little Hagia Sophia in Constantinople (begun in 527) is completed as the Church of Saints Sergius and Bacchus.

events.text: Extreme weather events of 535–536, thought to have been caused by an extensive veil of dust in the atmosphere, begin in the Northern Hemisphere. They continue until the following year, causing unseasonal weather and crop failure worldwide. It is possible this is caused by the eruption of a volcano: Ilopango in El Salvador (Central America); in North America; or in Iceland.[1]
events.html: Extreme weather events of 535–536, thought to have been caused by an extensive veil of dust in the atmosphere, begin in the Northern Hemisphere. They continue until the following year, causing unseasonal weather and crop failure worldwide. It is possible this is caused by the eruption of a volcano: Ilopango in El Salvador (Central America); in North America; or in Iceland.[1]

births.name: unknown date – Li Ezi

deaths.text: January 25 – Ankan, emperor of Japan (b. c. 466)
deaths.html: January 25 – Ankan, emperor of Japan (b. c. 466)
April 22 – Pope Agapetus I[12]

deaths.text: December – Theodahad, king of the Ostrogoths (assassinated) (b. c. 480)
deaths.html: December – Theodahad, king of the Ostrogoths (assassinated) (b. c. 480)

deaths.text: unknown date – Mundus, Gepid Byzantine general (killed in action)[13]
deaths.html: unknown date – Mundus, Gepid Byzantine general (killed in action)[13]
